sections.title: 1ï¸âƒ£ Package Statement â€” Organizing Your Code

A package is a folder-like structure that organizes related classes.

â€¢ java.util â†’ Utility classes (ArrayList, Scanner)
â€¢ java.io â†’ Input/Output classes
â€¢ com.example.myapp â†’ Your custom package

Packages prevent naming conflicts and organize large projects.

subsections.content:
Three main reasons:

1ï¸âƒ£ Organization
   Keep related classes together
   Makes large projects manageable

2ï¸âƒ£ Avoid Name Conflicts
   Two classes can have the same name in different packages
   com.example.Utils vs org.company.Utils âœ…

3ï¸âƒ£ Access Control
   Package-private access level
   Control which classes can see each other

â€¢ Ravi at 456 Oak Avenue

â€¢ com.example.Utils
â€¢ org.company.Utils

â€¢ 500 classes
â€¢ All in one folder

â€¢ All lowercase
â€¢ Reverse domain name: com.company.project
â€¢ Hierarchical: com.company.project.module.feature

â€¢ com.google.android
â€¢ org.apache.commons
â€¢ com.example.myapp.controllers

sections.title: 2ï¸âƒ£ Import Statements â€” Borrowing Tools
sections.content: Import statements tell Java which existing classes you want to use from other packages. They save you from writing fully qualified names everywhere.

subsections.title: ğŸ§  What Are Imports?
subsections.content:
Imports tell Java:
'Hey, I want to use this existing class from another package.'

Without import:
java.util.Scanner sc = new java.util.Scanner(System.in); âŒ (too long!)

With import:
import java.util.Scanner;
Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in); âœ… (clean!)

subsections.title: ğŸ¯ Why Imports Exist
subsections.content:
Three main benefits:

1ï¸âƒ£ Reuse Existing Code
   Java has thousands of built-in classes
   Don't reinvent the wheel!

2ï¸âƒ£ Cleaner Code
   Use short names instead of fully qualified names

3ï¸âƒ£ Organize Dependencies
   See exactly which external classes you're using

subsections.title: ğŸ§° The Toolbox Analogy

Imports are like borrowing tools from a toolbox:

ğŸ”¨ Why build a hammer when one exists?
ğŸ”§ Why create a Scanner when Java provides one?

Java's libraries are your toolbox:
â€¢ java.util â†’ Collection tools
â€¢ java.io â†’ File handling tools
â€¢ java.net â†’ Network tools

Import = Grabbing the tool you need!

subsections.title: ğŸ˜„ Without Imports...
subsections.content:
Imagine cooking without utensils:

'I'll cook pasta... but without pots, pans, or spoons!' ğŸğŸ˜„

'I'll write a program... but create everything from scratch!'

subsections.title: ğŸ“‹ Import Best Practices
subsections.content:
âœ… DO:
â€¢ Import specific classes: import java.util.ArrayList;
â€¢ Group imports logically
â€¢ Remove unused imports

âŒ DON'T:
â€¢ Use wildcard imports: import java.util.*; (unclear what you're using)
â€¢ Import classes from default package (java.lang) - already imported!
â€¢ Import classes you don't use

subsections.title: ğŸ’¡ Fun Fact: java.lang

â€¢ System
â€¢ Math
â€¢ Integer, Double, etc.

subsections.title: ğŸ§  What Is a Class?
subsections.content:
A class is a blueprint that defines:
â€¢ Properties (variables/fields)
â€¢ Behaviors (methods)
â€¢ Structure of objects

In Java:
â— Everything MUST be inside a class
â— No standalone functions/variables allowed
â— Object-oriented = class-oriented

subsections.title: ğŸ¯ Why Classes Exist
subsections.content:
Java is object-oriented, so:

1ï¸âƒ£ Organization
   Classes group related data and methods

2ï¸âƒ£ Reusability
   Create objects from class blueprints

3ï¸âƒ£ Encapsulation
   Hide internal details, expose what's needed

4ï¸âƒ£ Real-world Modeling
   Classes represent real entities (Student, Car, Account)

subsections.title: ğŸ“ The Blueprint Analogy
subsections.content:
Class = Blueprint of a house ğŸ“
Object = Actual house built from blueprint ğŸ 

Example:

â€¢ Has name, age, rollNo
â€¢ Can study(), attendClass()

Actual Houses (Objects):
â€¢ Student s1 = new Student('Alice', 20);
â€¢ Student s2 = new Student('Bob', 21);

One blueprint, many houses! One class, many objects!

subsections.title: âš ï¸ Java's Strict Rule
ğŸ“ Class Naming Rules
subsections.content:
âœ… MUST follow:
â€¢ Start with uppercase letter
â€¢ Use PascalCase: HelloWorld, StudentInfo
â€¢ No spaces or special characters
â€¢ Should be a noun (represents a thing)

âœ… Good names:
â€¢ Student, Employee, BankAccount

âŒ Bad names:
â€¢ myclass (lowercase)
â€¢ 123Student (starts with digit)

subsections.title: ğŸ”‘ Public Class Rule
subsections.content:
âš ï¸ Critical rule:
If a class is declared public, the filename MUST match!

public class HelloWorld { }

âœ… Filename must be: HelloWorld.java
âŒ HelloWorld.txt â†’ Won't work
âŒ helloworld.java â†’ Won't work (case-sensitive!)

One file = One public class

sections.content: The main method is the starting point of every Java application. When you run a program, the JVM loads the class, looks for main, and starts execution from there. No main = No execution!

subsections.title: ğŸ§  What Is the main Method?
subsections.content:
The main method is:
â€¢ The entry point of your Java program
â€¢ Where execution begins
â€¢ Required for standalone applications
â€¢ Called automatically by JVM

ğŸ“ When you run: java HelloWorld

JVM does:

2. Searches for main method

main is like:

subsections.title: âš ï¸ What If main Is Missing?
ğŸ“Š Execution Flow

Step-by-step what happens:

1ï¸âƒ£ You compile: javac HelloWorld.java
   â†’ Creates HelloWorld.class (bytecode)

sections.title: ğŸ” Breaking Down: public static void main(String[] args)
sections.content: Let's decode the most important method signature in Java, word by word. This is interview gold! Every keyword has a specific purpose and reason.

images.caption: Detailed breakdown of each component in the main method signature - public, static, void, main, String[] args - with explanations and visual aids

subsections.title: ğŸ“‹ Complete Breakdown Table
subsections.content:
Part          | Meaning                | Why Needed
------------- | ---------------------- | -------------------------------------
public        | Accessible everywhere  | JVM must access it from outside
static        | No object needed       | JVM doesn't create objects to run main
void          | No return value        | JVM doesn't expect anything back
main          | Method name            | JVM looks for this exact name
String[] args | Command-line arguments | Accept input at runtime

ğŸ¯ Every word matters! Change one and it won't work!

subsections.title: ğŸ”“ public â€” Open to All
subsections.content:
Why public?

JVM is outside your class and needs to access main.

âŒ If private:
JVM: 'Sorry, I can't access this!' â†’ Error

âœ… If public:
JVM: 'Perfect, I can call this!' â†’ Runs

ğŸšª Analogy:
Front door must be public, not locked!
If locked, guests can't enter. ğŸ”ğŸ˜„

Reason: JVM is an external caller that needs access.

subsections.title: âš¡ static â€” No Object Required
subsections.content:
Why static?

JVM doesn't want to create objects just to run your program.

Without static:
JVM would need to do:
HelloWorld obj = new HelloWorld(); âŒ
obj.main(args); âŒ
Too much work!

With static:
JVM directly calls:
HelloWorld.main(args); âœ…
No object needed!

â˜ï¸ Analogy:
Calling customer care:
â€¢ You don't need to know the agent personally
â€¢ Just dial and talk
â€¢ static = Direct access without knowing anyone

Reason: Simplifies program startup - no object construction needed.

subsections.title: ğŸš« void â€” No Return Value
subsections.content:
Why void?

main doesn't return anything to JVM.

JVM says:
'Just run the program, no receipt needed!' ğŸ˜„

If main returned something:
public static int main(String[] args) {
    return 42; // JVM: 'What do I do with this?' ğŸ¤·
}

JVM doesn't care about return values from main.

ğŸ Analogy:
You give a gift to someone.
They say 'Thanks!' and keep it.
They don't give you a receipt! ğŸ˜„

Reason: Main is the starting point, not a subroutine that returns data.

subsections.title: ğŸ¯ main â€” The Magic Name
subsections.content:
Why 'main'?

It's a fixed convention! JVM only recognizes this name.

âŒ Try renaming:
public static void start(String[] args) { }
public static void run(String[] args) { }
public static void begin(String[] args) { }

JVM: 'Error: Main method not found' ğŸ˜µ

âœ… Must be exactly:
public static void main(String[] args) { }

JVM: 'Found it! Let's go!' ğŸš€

ğŸ” Analogy:
Like a secret password.
JVM asks: 'What's the password?'
You must say: 'main'
Say anything else = Access denied!

Reason: JVM specification requires this exact name for program entry point.

subsections.title: ğŸ“¦ String[] args â€” Command-Line Arguments
subsections.content:
Why String[] args?

Allows passing input when running the program.

Example:
java MyProgram hello world 123

Inside program:
args[0] â†’ 'hello'
args[1] â†’ 'world'
args[2] â†’ '123'

ğŸ Analogy:
args is like a gift box ğŸ
JVM hands it to your program at startup.
You can open it and use what's inside!

ğŸ’¡ Note:
â€¢ Always an array of Strings
â€¢ Can be empty: new String[0]
â€¢ Can rename: String[] parameters (works, but args is convention)

Reason: Provides flexibility to pass runtime arguments without recompiling.

subsections.title: ğŸ§  Breaking Down System.out.println
subsections.content:
Let's decode Java's most famous statement:

ğŸ“Œ System
â€¢ A built-in utility class (from java.lang)

ğŸ“Œ out

â€¢ Represents standard output (console/terminal)

ğŸ“Œ println
â€¢ A method of PrintStream class
â€¢ Prints text + adds new line
â€¢ println = print + line break

subsections.title: ğŸ—£ï¸ The Speaking Analogy

System.out.println is Java saying:

subsections.title: ğŸ“Š Step-by-Step Execution
subsections.content:
1ï¸âƒ£ You write code
   HelloWorld.java (source file)

2ï¸âƒ£ You compile
   javac HelloWorld.java
   â†’ Creates HelloWorld.class (bytecode)

3ï¸âƒ£ You run
   java HelloWorld
   â†’ JVM starts

4ï¸âƒ£ JVM loads the class
   â†’ Reads HelloWorld.class
   â†’ Loads into memory

5ï¸âƒ£ JVM looks for main
   â†’ Searches: public static void main(String[] args)
   â†’ Found? â†’ Continue
   â†’ Not found? â†’ Error!

6ï¸âƒ£ Execution starts from main
   â†’ Line by line execution
   â†’ Top to bottom

7ï¸âƒ£ Statements execute
   â†’ Variables created
   â†’ Methods called
   â†’ Output produced

8ï¸âƒ£ main method ends
   â†’ Program terminates
   â†’ JVM shuts down

subsections.title: â±ï¸ Real-Time Example
ğŸ¬ Movie Analogy
subsections.content:
Think of program execution like watching a movie:

ğŸ¬ Opening scene â†’ main method starts
ğŸ“½ï¸ Scenes play â†’ Statements execute one by one
ğŸ­ Characters act â†’ Objects interact, methods called
ğŸµ Background music â†’ JVM managing memory
ğŸ¬ Ending credits â†’ main method ends

Just like you can't skip the opening scene,

sections.title: ğŸ“ Common Mistakes & How to Avoid Them
sections.content: Learning from common mistakes helps you become a better programmer faster.

subsections.title: âŒ Mistake #1: Filename Doesn't Match Class Name
subsections.content:
Wrong:
public class HelloWorld { }
Filename: Test.java âŒ

Error: 'class HelloWorld is public, should be declared in a file named HelloWorld.java'

Correct:
public class HelloWorld { }
Filename: HelloWorld.java âœ…

ğŸ’¡ Remember: Public class name MUST match filename exactly (case-sensitive)!

subsections.title: âŒ Mistake #2: Typo in main Method
subsections.content:
Wrong:
public static void Main(String[] args) { } // Capital M
public static void main(String args) { }    // Missing []

static void main(String[] args) { }          // Missing public

All result in: 'Error: Main method not found'

Correct:
public static void main(String[] args) { } âœ…

ğŸ’¡ Every character matters! Copy it exactly.

subsections.title: âŒ Mistake #3: Missing Semicolon
subsections.content:
Wrong:
System.out.println("Hello") // Missing semicolon

Error: '; expected'

Correct:
System.out.println("Hello"); âœ…

ğŸ’¡ Every statement must end with semicolon (except blocks like if, for, etc.)

subsections.title: âŒ Mistake #4: Wrong Quotes
subsections.content:
Wrong:
System.out.println('Hello');  // Single quotes for string
System.out.println("Hello");   // Smart quotes (curly)

Error: 'Unclosed character literal' or 'Illegal character'

Correct:

ğŸ’¡ Strings use double quotes (\"), characters use single quotes ('a')

subsections.title: âŒ Mistake #5: Code Outside Class
ğŸ’¡ Pro Tips to Avoid Mistakes
subsections.content:
1ï¸âƒ£ Use an IDE (IntelliJ, Eclipse, VS Code)

2ï¸âƒ£ Copy-paste the main signature initially

3ï¸âƒ£ Pay attention to case

4ï¸âƒ£ Check your brackets

5ï¸âƒ£ Read error messages carefully

keyPoints: Every Java program must have at least one class - code cannot exist outside a class
The main method signature must be exactly: public static void main(String[] args)
public allows JVM to access main from outside the class
static allows JVM to call main without creating an object
void means main doesn't return any value to the JVM
'main' is the exact method name JVM looks for - it cannot be renamed
String[] args holds command-line arguments passed to the program
Package statement (optional) organizes classes into namespaces
Import statements (optional) allow using classes from other packages
Public class name must exactly match the filename (case-sensitive)
System.out.println() is used to print output to the console
JVM loads the class, finds main, and starts execution from there
Execution flow: compile â†’ load class â†’ find main â†’ execute statements â†’ terminate
One .java file can have only one public class
Every statement (except blocks) must end with a semicolon
Java is case-sensitive: Main â‰  main, String â‰  string
The main method is the entry point for standalone Java applications

interviewQA.question: What is the main method in Java?
interviewQA.answer: The main method is the entry point of a Java application. It's where program execution begins. JVM looks for this method when you run a Java program. Signature must be: public static void main(String[] args)

interviewQA.question: Why is main method public in Java?
interviewQA.answer: The main method is public because JVM needs to access it from outside the class. If it were private or protected, JVM couldn't call it to start the program. Public access allows JVM (an external caller) to invoke the method.

interviewQA.question: Why is main method static in Java?
interviewQA.answer: The main method is static so JVM can call it without creating an object of the class. If it weren't static, JVM would need to instantiate the class first, which is unnecessary and inefficient for program startup. Static allows direct invocation: ClassName.main(args)

interviewQA.question: Why does main method return void?
interviewQA.answer: The main method returns void because JVM doesn't expect any return value. The method's purpose is to start and run the program, not to return data. Program exit status is controlled through System.exit(int) if needed, not through main's return value.

interviewQA.question: What is String[] args in main method?
interviewQA.answer: String[] args is an array of command-line arguments passed to the program at runtime. When you run 'java MyClass arg1 arg2', args[0] = 'arg1' and args[1] = 'arg2'. It allows passing input without recompiling the program. The name 'args' is convention but can be changed.

interviewQA.question: Can we have multiple main methods in a Java program?
interviewQA.answer: Yes, you can have multiple main methods in different classes within the same program. Each class can have its own main method. When you run the program (java ClassName), JVM executes the main method of that specific class. However, only one public class per file, and filename must match that public class.

interviewQA.question: What happens if we don't define main method in a class?
interviewQA.answer: If you try to run a class without a main method, you'll get a runtime error: 'Error: Main method not found in class ClassName'. The class will compile fine, but JVM cannot execute it as a standalone application. Libraries/utility classes don't need main, but executable classes do.

interviewQA.question: Can we change the name of main method?
interviewQA.answer: No, you cannot rename main to something else (like 'start' or 'run') for the entry point. JVM specifically looks for a method named 'main' with exact signature. You can create other methods with different names, but they won't be execution entry points.

interviewQA.question: What is the sequence of execution in a Java program?
interviewQA.answer: 1) Compile: javac creates .class bytecode. 2) Run: java command starts JVM. 3) JVM loads the class into memory. 4) JVM searches for public static void main(String[] args). 5) Execution begins from first statement in main. 6) Statements execute sequentially. 7) main ends, program terminates.

interviewQA.question: Why must the public class name match the filename?
interviewQA.answer: In Java, if a class is declared public, the filename must exactly match the class name (case-sensitive) with .java extension. This helps JVM locate the class file. It's a design decision for organization and clarity. One file can have only one public class, but multiple non-public classes.

interviewQA.question: What is System.out.println()?
interviewQA.answer: System.out.println() is used to print output to console. System is a class in java.lang, 'out' is a static PrintStream object, println() is a method that prints and adds a newline. It's the most common way to display output in Java programs.

interviewQA.question: Can we overload the main method?
interviewQA.answer: Yes, you can overload main method by creating methods with the same name but different parameters. However, JVM will only call public static void main(String[] args) as the entry point. Other overloaded versions must be called explicitly from within the program.
